text: When I notice early signs of depression like mental fog or energy drops, I intervene before they become heavy burdens.
I recognize the difference between emotional truth and actual truth when my mind shifts toward darker conclusions.
When I feel the weight in my thoughts or slowdown in my body, I see it as a signal my system needs support.
I let depression feel like a personal flaw without recognizing it as information about my inner system.
I notice when my mind exaggerates problems or predicts failure, and I challenge these thoughts with balanced thinking.
When I recognize emotional dips or motivation drops, I prepare for difficult days instead of being surprised by them.
I see depression as a signal my inner system is overloaded, not as an identity that defines my self-worth.
I let negative spirals pull me into isolation or avoidance without slowing the intensity or staying grounded.
When I feel heavy or overwhelmed, I breathe and ground myself instead of collapsing or withdrawing completely.
I recognize when my thoughts drift into extremes, and I pause and redirect my attention to restore balance.
When I notice recurring thoughts that increase heaviness, I identify them and create space for improvement.
I let emotional hooks like certain people or environments drain my mood without creating boundaries to protect it.
I notice when I'm confusing who I am with what I feel, and I separate my identity from my emotions.
When I recognize cognitive distortions like catastrophizing or overgeneralizing, I question and correct them.
I see how sleep, stress, memories, or pressure affect my inner balance, and I adjust my environment accordingly.
I let depression push me into self-criticism or isolation without choosing behaviors that support me.
When I feel my motivation dropping, I create a low-energy plan with small steps that bring calm.
I recognize when my mind forgets past successes or focuses only on problems, and I restore balanced thinking.
When I notice depressive waves starting, I track their signals and manage them strategically instead of fearing them.
I let emotional fog or memory weakness interfere with my thinking without challenging distorted thoughts or restoring clarity.
